case.name: Twining v Australian Public Service Commission [2006] FCA 129 (16 February 2006)

citphrases.citphrase: state service investigation into possible breaches of code of conduct
investigation mandated where head of agency held belief of possible breach on reasonable grounds
whether terms of scheme required hearing before investigation initiated
consideration of investigatory and decision-making scheme as a whole.

citances.sentence: 17 The Attorney-General points to the availability of review under s50 of the SSA in respect of the conduct of the investigation, but moreover relies on the proposition that to intervene at this stage would cause disadvantageous delays and fragment ongoing proceedings, the undesirability of which, in the absence of a clearly discernible benefit, was noted by Evans J (Crawford J agreeing) in Port of Devonport Corporation Pty Ltd v Abey [2005] TASSC 97 ; (2005) 15 Tas R 158 at [35] , [48] --- [49]. See also Wilson v Co-ordinator-General Department of State Development [2001] QSCA 159 at [13] and, in this particular context, Twining v Australian Public Service Commission [2006] FCA 129 at [19] .
The respondent relied on the decisions in Lawrence v Attorney-General (Grenada) [214] and Twining v Australian Public Service Commission [2006] FCA 129 in this regard.

ADMINISTRATIVE DECISIONS (JUDICIAL REVIEW) ACT 1977 - SECT 11 Manner of making applications
